sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Welcome to Euronews tonight, I'm Maryam Zaidi. Here are the headlines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: WHO says Omicron has now been detected in 23 countries as EU member states impose stricter travel restrictions to counter the variant spread.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, nearly two-thirds of citizens in North Macedonia still believe unfounded theories about coronavirus. That's according to a new study.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: NATO calls on Russia to re-engage in talks with Ukraine to de-escalate tensions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Kiev urges the alliance to be ready to impose sanctions on Moscow if it makes a move.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: And how a priceless Caravaggio on the wall of this Italian villa has sent its auction price skyrocketing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The World Health Organization says the Omicron variant has now been reported in 23 countries around the world

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: and says it expects that number to rise rapidly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The health body says it expects to see the first data on how transmissible the strain is in the coming days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Early evidence is suggesting that Omicron doesn't cause severe illness and that the vaccine efficacy is not reduced by it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: But the World Health Organization says vaccine mask wearing and social distancing are still the best way to contain the virus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The WHO head says ending the pandemic is not a matter of time, it's a matter of choice.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Globally, we have a toxic mix of low vaccine coverage and very low testing, a recipe for breeding and amplifying variants.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: That's why we continue to urge countries to fully fund the ACT Accelerator to ensure equitable access to vaccines, tests, therapeutics all over the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Germany has recorded its highest number of COVID-related deaths since February and more than 67,000 new cases. Its infectious disease agency says a new pandemic peak will be reached by mid-December.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Doctors are warning that at least 6,000 people could have need for ICU care, regardless of measures being imposed now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The EU has brought forward the availability of vaccines for children by two weeks. The EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen says she's spoken with German US vaccine makers, Pfizer and BioNTech, to guarantee access to a new batch. She also says bloc members should make COVID vaccines mandatory because too many people are still refusing to get shots voluntarily. We are in kind of a tug of war. On the one hand, you have the virus and the variants. And on the other hand, we have vaccination and boosters.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And I want the second part to win. Well, for more for the picture across the Bloc,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: we now go to Brussels to our correspondent Shona Murray, who's in Brussels. Shona, thanks for joining. So we've just seen Ursula von der Leyen there supporting mandatory vaccination. Several EU countries are actually considering this. Are vaccine drives and travel restrictions at the core of the EU response?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: core of the EU response? Well, I think she was very, you know, she knew and she pointed out that this is very much a member state competence. So she doesn't have any position. The EU has no role in talking to member states about mandatory vaccines. It's a complete member state competence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So, but she made the point that she never thought she'd see the day that we have this deadly virus, this deadly crushing virus, and we have vaccines, yet one third of the EU population is unwilling to get vaccinated. That's about 150 million people. She also made the point that out of that, there are many people who can't get vaccinated for medical reasons, and of course, small children under the age of five, so that everybody else who can get vaccinated has an obligation to protect those who can't and so she said it's something that needs to be discussed um but of course um we've seen some countries austria in particular going ahead and saying that there will be mandatory vaccination by february because of course you see all across europe a disproportionate number of people in icus that are unvaccinated. Those who are in hospital that have been vaccinated often have underlying conditions. And on the travel restrictions, I think the emphasis is on trying to keep the single market as open as possible and making sure that people are vaccinated so they can move around. But we've seen a number of member states, Ireland, Portugal, for example, ensuring that people still have a negative PCR test regardless of their vaccination status.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Now, Sona, negotiations are on a deal to allow developing countries to produce COVID-19 vaccines, which the EU is part of, was postponed because of the spread of Omicron. But this is exactly what was being called for. Yeah, it's almost really well, it is ironic really that the meeting in relation to future variants and ensuring the developing countries can make vaccines to prevent future variants was cancelled because of an escape variant. But there is no agreement on this yet. The EU's position is and it has moved from its original position is that they will allow for compulsory licensing for COVID vaccines only for developing countries. So if a country like South Africa or others want to take the license, then the Belgian government can force, let's say Pfizer or someone, to hand over the details of that. NGOs and others say that they want a complete intellectual property waiver because the other way is way too complicated. The WTO was near an agreement on this this week but obviously has been stalled.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But the EU, as Nurse Lavonda Lyons said today, that they are pretty much on the same page.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They want developing countries to be able to make their own vaccines. But they also make the point that regardless of countries being able to make their own vaccines, there are still obstacles and manufacturing obstacles and also a huge problem, which is vaccine hesitancy, which actually is an issue across the world. Shona, thanks so much for joining us on the programme. A new poll has found that nearly two thirds of citizens in North Macedonia believe

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: that COVID-19 was created to control humans.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: This study found a significant number of Macedonians believe other unfounded claims too.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Matthew in the Cube has more on this story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: As the continent struggles with the new Omicron variant of coronavirus, citizens in the east of Europe are seeing vaccine hesitancy rates fly, sales in fake coronavirus certificates are flourishing and conspiracy theories dominate the conversation. And now a new study has revealed the true scale of the issue in the Republic of North Macedonia. This poll was conducted by the Societas Sefilis Institute for Democracy. They surveyed 1,000 people in North Macedonia aged over 18 and these were their findings. They found that nearly 65% of people believe the unfounded theory that COVID-19 was created in a laboratory to control humans. While the World Health Organization has investigated the possibility that COVID-19 originated in a lab, there is no evidence to suggest it was created to supposedly control humans. Meanwhile the study found that 46% of people believe the theory that planes have been spraying the virus across North Macedonia. That is a baseless and debunked claim.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And 46% of people believe another unfounded theory that hospitals and the health ministry in North Macedonia have been amplifying the number of victims of Covid-19 because they are being paid to do so. Now analysts say that these kind of conspiracy theories are unsurprising given the amount of distrust in politicians and democratic institutions. North Macedonia authorities have been accused of mismanagement such as in September when 14 people were killed in a fire at a COVID-19 hospital in Tetevo. And analysts also say that a rise in populism in the country has contributed to the prevalence of these conspiracy theories. And these unfounded claims don't just relate to the coronavirus. That study also found that 29% of people in North Macedonia say they believe that climate change is a hoax. Meanwhile, a massive 72% of people in North Macedonia say they believe that climate change is a hoax.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, a massive 72% of people say they believe that the world is controlled by a handful of powerful families. Both unfounded claims. Earlier I spoke to journalist Bojan Stojkovski and he told me that the Covid-19 pandemic has been amplifying unfounded theories like this and making them commonplace for many in North Macedonia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The rise of fake news here has been well documented years before.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And I think that with the pandemic, it only serves to add another dimension.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Conspiracy theories and the trust in authorities, especially health authorities, I think are connected to each other. We definitely needed to have more efficient campaigns that would prevent all of this. So now we are only facing with the consequences and we are just trying to have some sort of damage control.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: North Macedonia, like many countries in Europe, battling a high level of infections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: But polls still showing that many in the country believe unfounded and baseless theories about the pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Marianne.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Thanks, Matthew.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: That is quite the conspiracy theory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Ukraine has asked NATO to prepare a sanctions package against Russia in an effort to deter

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: it from starting an invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: NATO foreign ministers have been meeting for a second day in the Latvian capital Riga, where talks have been dominated by Russia's military build-up on its border with Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Seven years ago, Russia seized Crimea and then later annexed the territory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The US is particularly concerned over troop movements on the border and what Russia could be planning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: DONALD TRUMP, President of the United States, We don't know whether President Putin has made the decision to invade.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We do know that he is putting in place the capacity to do so on short order, should he so decide.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So despite uncertainty about intentions and timing, we must prepare for all contingencies while working to see to it that Russia reverses course.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, Ukraine's president has said it needs to have direct talks with Moscow to try to end the ongoing war with Russian-backed separatists in the east of the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: More than 14,000 people have died in the conflict since 2014. Let's now go to Kiev and to Peter Dickinson, the Ukrainian editor at the Atlantic Council. Peter, good to have you on the program. So fears of this Russian escalation in Ukraine really dominating this NATO foreign ministers meeting. But with Ukraine not a NATO member, what leverage does the alliance really have?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: With Ukraine not a NATO member, what leverage does the alliance really have?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Thank you for having me, Mariam. It's a pleasure to join you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's limited what NATO can actually put on the table. At the moment, obviously, all sides, NATO itself, Ukraine and Russia, are aware that there is no real option of any military involvement from the NATO side.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So what we're really talking about is economic sanctions, perhaps some political sanctions as well, but fundamentally it will be economic measures that would hopefully restrain Russia and cause them to think twice.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We've had the US Secretary of State talking about measures that have not previously been considered.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Some have speculated this may mean removal or restriction of Russia's access to things like the international SWIFT banking system, which would have a major impact on the Russian economy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The question is whether these economic factors will be enough to deter Russia from something that many believe is a fundamental foreign policy priority for President Putin, which is to reassert Russian authority over Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Exactly. So economic sanctions may or may not work.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: But what about also then restarting dialogue with Russia?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: That's also being called for.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: What do you think is really the best approach to try to de-escalate this?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, Ukraine has been quite vocal in recent days, again, saying they want to have direct talk with Russia. They want to sit down. President Zelensky wants to sit down with President Putin. They want to talk. They want to engage. They need to engage. But the question is whether Russia has any interest in that kind of head-to-head, face-to-face engagement. On the contrary, Russia has been quite clear. Mr. Putin himself wrote a very long essay in the summer of 2021, and then that was followed by a similar essay by his predecessor and former Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev, in which they both said very clearly that Ukraine was not a sovereign nation, was under control of the West. And they seem to be looking to speak directly over Ukraine's head to the leaders of the Western world, America and NATO leaders, cutting Ukraine out of a dialogue, essentially talking about Ukraine without Ukraine. So the question now in terms of dialogue is who would that dialogue be between?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And it's not clear that Russia has any interest in speaking with Ukraine at this point. So be between. And it's not clear that Russia has any interest in speaking with Ukraine at this point. So it may be that Russia is angling for a summit meeting with President Biden. That's certainly something that's being widely speculated at the moment. Will America offer that or not? Also, on the question, will it be enough? But I personally have significant doubts that Russia has any interest at all engaging with Ukraine directly. So it looks like at the moment it's at the top table, as it were, geopolitically in terms of international relations, where they're looking to strike some sort of a grand deal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Really interesting analysis there, Peter. Thanks so much for joining us on the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Peter Dickinson, the Ukraine editor at the Atlantic Council. Well, still to come, we'll be live in Washington, D.C., as the Supreme Court hears a case to ban abortion after 15 weeks in Mississippi.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: That story coming up on Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The US Supreme Court has begun hearing arguments

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: in a case that could decide the future of access to abortion in the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: It centers around a 2018 Mississippi law that bans most terminations after 15 weeks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The judges are being asked to decide if the law is unconstitutional.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Campaigners say the case threatens the legal underpinnings of Roe v. Wade.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The outcome could be a turning point in the country's history.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Well, for more on this now, we're going to go to DC to our reporter, Ray Suarez, for more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Ray, good to have you on the programme. So the case is being heard. It's one of the most important cases on abortion in the US for decades, but we don't expect a ruling until January.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Bill, what's at stake?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Well, a lot is at stake, Mariam.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The argument wrapped up just a few minutes ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It was carried on at a very high level, and it went to this basic question.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Who gets to decide whether a woman must carry a pregnancy to term or whether she is free to end that pregnancy if she so chooses? Intense argument, questions from the justices of the Supreme Court, two lawyers on the various sides. What's at stake? If the Mississippi law is upheld by the justices of the Supreme Court, it will leave states likely free to go their own way on abortion, to no longer be controlled by the precedents set by the Roe v. Wade decision in the early 1970s. This has been a titanic 50-year battle over the right to abortion in the United States.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Instead of coming to an end, it will just open up a new front in that seemingly endless political war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: But you're likely, if the Mississippi law stands, to end with a country where on one side of a state border a woman may terminate her pregnancy, but on the other side of that border, maybe a 10-minute drive away, it might be, strictly speaking, illegal under almost any circumstances. It will leave state legislators free to go their own way and open a whole new battle in this war. Mariam? So, Ray, you talk about this being a titanic abortion battle.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Set the scene at the Supreme Court itself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: We're seeing protesters from both pro- and anti-abortion groups.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: This has been one of the major pillars around which American politics has been carried on since the Roe v. Wade decision in 1973.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Anti-groups, pro-groups have supported politicians, raised millions of dollars, become activists, set off legal battles in the various states.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: This has been one of the single largest issues in the great debates of American political life.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Interestingly, abortion itself is at a 50-year low. Fewer American women every year try to get a surgical procedure to end a pregnancy. But even as abortion recedes in actual fact in American life, as the availability of both reproductive education and contraception widen for American women of any age, the policy at the core of the battle remains front and center in American politics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: That's why this has been so consequential, and now we're seeing, in actual fact, the real impact of a one-term president, Donald Trump, being able to seat three justices on what's now perceived as a conservative majority court with a 6-3 conservative majority that is anti-abortion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Mariam?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Ray, thanks for that really important update from DC.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The EU wants to improve links with the developing world with an aim of countering the increased

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: influence of China's Belt and Road Initiative.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Christopher Pitchers reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Three hundred billion euros, the amount earmarked by Brussels on Wednesday to boost links with the developing world in response to the growing influence of China.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: On the face of it, the European Commission's so-called Global Gateway aims to invest billions in poorer countries by 2027 to help them with infrastructure projects they can't afford on their own.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But at the heart of it is a strategy designed to rival Beijing's own Belt and Road Initiative and also to offer an alternative.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: They know we are transparent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: They know it is accompanied by good governance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: They know there will be no unsustainable debt levels as a leftover. Also that the local communities really benefit from the added value of infrastructure investment. And we bring on top the private sector with us, a private sector that in such a way does not exist in China. So it is a true alternative. Brussels wants the main areas of investment to be in digital projects, transport, health, climate and energy, and finally in education and research.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But China's Belt and Road Initiative, a huge collection of global infrastructure projects, has already been up and running since 2013. Despite Brussels' late entry into the game, one of the EU's leading lawmakers on Chinese affairs says it's already having an impact on Beijing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: I would say that even the discussion around global gateway has already had an effect on China.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: If people listen carefully to what's being said from Beijing, all of a sudden Xi Jinping talks about quality projects.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: That's new.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: All of a sudden he talks about sustainability.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: That's new.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The fact that China is now owning up to these criteria is already a positive effect that we're having.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And in that regard, I welcome any competition. The commission didn't give specific examples of what projects will be invested in, but it said things like extensive transport links and underwater data cables connecting continents will likely be possible. Christopher Pitcher, Euronews, Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Edges Euronews, Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: We're going to take a short break, but if you have a spare €471 million, and you love art, you could buy a very special villa in Italy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: That story coming up after the break.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to Euronews Tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: A rather unique villa is going up for auction in Italy with a multi-million euro guide price.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Now it's up to the Ministry of Culture to match whatever sum is bid, if it wishes to stop the property going to a private owner.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Thomas Blade explained what makes the house so special. Take a look.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Rita Boncampani Ludovici opens the doors of one of Italy's most famous villas. The Texan native inherited Casino dell'Aurora following the death of her aristocratic husband.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And what makes this Roman residence stand out? It contains a one-of-a-kind Caravaggio artwork.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: This work is unique because it is a mural by Caravaggio, who did no other mural paintings.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: All his works are on canvas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It is a mythological subject, and this, too, is unique, or almost, because it represents the three Greek divinities who preside over the sky, the sea and the earth, namely Jupiter, Neptune and Pluto.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: MALCOLM BRABANT, Diplomat and patron of the arts Cardinal del Monte commissioned Caravaggio's masterpiece in 1597. It's so important to future generations and I think to Italy too. I think this house is important for Italians. It shouldn't be made into an apartment building or you know business.
